awd_titl_txt: CAREER: ECO-EVOLUTIONARY DYNAMICS: WHAT ARE THE CAUSAL LINKS BETWEEN POPULATION DENSITY, NATURAL SELECTION AND PHENOTYPIC CHANGE?
awd_abstract_narration:
Fostering the development of early-career teacher-scholars strengthens the nation's research capacity while contributing to an educated workforce capable of making complex decisions. This CAREER project integrates interdisciplinary research and creative educational opportunities to gain novel insights into the causal links between evolutionary change and population ecology. Natural selection, phenotypic change, and population size are often related, but we know little about the causes that underlie these relationships.  The research takes advantage of rapid evolutionary change observed in the invasive western bluebird to investigate these causal relationships, and engages high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to think critically in order to solve problems and answer questions. 

Western bluebirds depend on successional habitat and must continually colonize new areas to survive. In previous work, the investigator discovered rapid shifts in aggression, population density, and natural selection that accompanied recolonization cycles. Newly colonized populations have low density, high aggression, and positive selection on aggression; older populations have high density, low aggression, and strong negative selection on aggression. These recurring cycles provide a unique opportunity to investigate the causal links between population density, natural selection and phenotypic change. The investigator will combine several approaches to determine these links: experimental manipulation of population density; observations of how changing density correlates with aggression; experimental manipulation of food availability and survival to identify changes in aggression and population size; and estimation of quantitative genetic parameters related to aggressiveness. Results will be integrated to resolve the causal links between evolutionary (selection for aggression) and ecological (population density) changes in these populations. This system is exceptionally amenable to manipulation of ecological interactions through the provision of nesting boxes, and the need for western bluebirds to recolonize new areas requires rapid evolutionary change. The ability to study populations at different stages of a colonization cycle provides diverse contexts to examine the links between components of an eco-evolutionary feedback loop.  A particularly novel broader impact of this research is the engagement of cognitively delayed students to help them gain important life skills. Outreach to and collaboration with citizen scientists, the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes, conservation groups, wildlife officials, and landowners will significantly broaden educational opportunities and the dissemination of research results.

por.por_cntn:
Recent empirical studies have confirmed that rapid behavioral change in populations can influence population density, which in turn may affect natural selection on behavior, setting the stage for a feedback loop between behavioral change and ecological interactions. Yet, it is rarely possible to experimentally verify the causal links between the two since large-scale manipulation of population dynamics is difficult in wild populations. At the same time, isolating the mechanistic links is crucial for understanding how populations adapt to novel environments and how they respond to anthropogenic changes. In our study, we capitalized on an emerging model system for evolutionary ecology research ? competitive dynamics between mountain and western bluebirds (Sialia currucoides and S. mexicana) ? to investigate the causal links between population density, natural selection and behavioral change.

The main research goal of the project was to determine whether maternal effects or natural selection were most important in driving changes in behavior and how these changes influenced population dynamics. To accomplish this goal, we monitored hundreds of nests, banded more than 7,000 bluebirds across 10 sites in western Montana, and conducted behavioral assays on hundreds of pairs to assess aggressive behavior. We also collected DNA samples to construct pedigrees and confirm relatedness among individuals, and collected hormone samples to assess maternal stress levels. Finally, we carried out large-scale field experiments where we manipulated maternal environment by altering the number of nest boxes on territories to change the competitive environment.

The main finding was that stress-induced maternal effects on aggression and dispersal produced changes within populations each generation that directly influence population density. Specifically, mothers subject to environmental stressors (in the form of higher competition from competitors or inclement weather) during the time they are producing eggs were more likely to allocate high levels of testosterone to egg yolks. This steroid hormone has organizational effects on aggressive behavior during offspring development causing higher levels of aggression which allows offspring to leave their natal population and successfully colonize new populations elsewhere. Because of this influence on dispersal, the maternal effect directly impacts population density in the following year and because population density influences the maternal effect by altering competitive interactions this sets up the next round of stress-induced behavioral change in offspring. The reciprocal feedbacks between population density and offspring behavior were likely a historical adaptation to successional dynamics in post-fire forests and we found that they emerge spontaneously in novel contexts, demonstrating that self-organizing properties of ecological systems can be generated by individual differences in behavior that arise from local-scale responses. Thus, our results provide insight into how novel ecological dynamics can emerge on short time scales and emphasize that knowledge of adaptations in a species? historical habitat are crucial to interpreting how they will respond to human-induced changes in the environment. This project has led to 17 peer-reviewed publications with several more in progress.

The main teaching goals of this project have been fulfilled with the development of two new courses: Evolutionary Epigenetics, a graduate course emphasizing the role of maternal effects in adaptive evolution and a new research training course for undergraduate and graduate students Skills in Ornithology. This project also provided training for numerous trainees at all levels of education including one high school student, 17 undergraduates including 5 REU students, 6 graduate students (2 Ph.D., 2 Master?s and 2 visiting international students), 3 postdocs and one K-12 science teacher.

Broader Impacts

Results of this work were disseminated to the public through publication of 3 popular magazine articles in The Bluebird, Montana Outdoors, and Aeon. The PI has also given 12 university seminars, 2 plenary lectures, 10 symposium/workshop talks at international meetings, and two outreach lectures (at Tucson Audubon and Denver Museum of Natural History). There has been extensive coverage of this work in the media (National Geographic, CBS News, Nature World News, Science News and The Scientist) and in recently published books for the general public (The Science of Animal Personality by John Shivik and Birds of Montana by Marks et al.) as well as in an ornithological textbook (Ornithology edited by Morrison et al. 2018). Finally, this project expanded collaborations with K-12 teachers by providing opportunities for high school students in Missoula, MT to help with data collection at a field site where we give hands on demonstrations of techniques in field biology. It also established outreach and collaborative projects with Tucson Audubon and local schools in Tucson, including Imago Dei, a tuition-free private middle school in downtown Tucson serving only children from low-income families, including many refugees.
